Key Arguments: The bill infringes on the right to free speech.
It could lead to a one-sided debate and stifle scientific and societal progress.
The determination of misinformation and disinformation could be subjective and centralized, leading to potential abuse of power.
The bill could discourage critical thinking and open debate, especially among young people.
The implementation could be difficult and costly for digital platforms, potentially leading to restricted access for Australians.
The bill could increase distrust in democratic institutions.
Existing methods for addressing misinformation and abuse are sufficient.
Notable Quotes: A bill where the government decides what is truth sounds like a communistic idea, and should not be entertained in a democracy.
I am concerned that this bill will create a culture whereby younger people will be afraid to voice their thoughts or opinions.
This bill will make it extremely difficult for adjustments to acceptable information to be made.
